prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 345 GHz Continuum and Spectral Line Observations
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: High spatial and spectral resolution observations of dust continuum and HCN, H13CN and HC15N from our sample of 11 Class I protostars.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We request high spatial resolution so that we can well resolve the compact disks, and more importantly the planet forming regions in those disks, around Class I protostars. Planets are expected to form within a radius of ~50 AU, or a 0.6" diameter at 140 pc, so the requested resolution, of ~0.1" is essential for resolving these regions. If we were to use a lower frequency band, the best available spatial resolution would be a factor of two worse at 0.2". In order to accurately characterize both the disk and envelope, however we must also remain sensitive to large scale structures. We therefore also request observations with a compact configuration of the 12M array as well as the ACA.
Many of our targets have been previously observed at 1mm with a 1" beam (Eisner 2012) or with an 11" beam (Motte & Andre 2001). To estimate the flux per resolution element, of ~0.1" for the proposed extended configuration observations, we assume that previously measured millimeter fluxes for our targets trace an optically thin, face-on disk with a surface density profile Sigma ~ r^-1 and a temperature profile T ~ r^-0.5. We use that F_nu ~ nu^(2+beta) at millimeter wavelengths, with a reasonable assumption of beta=1 (e.g. Rodmann et al. 2006, Ricci et al. 2010a,b), to estimate the 870 micron fluxes. We find that our targets will have peak brightnesses of 15-170 mJy/beam in a 0.12" beam. For targets whose brightness is unknown we list a brightness of 15 mJy as their expected brightness. Our observations must be sensitive to emission from the extended envelope, which may be >10 times fainter than the peak brightness. We request a sensitivity of 0.5 mJy/beam so that our faintest targets will have a signal-to-noise ratio of 30, and the faint extended emission will be detectable with a signal-to-noise of ~3. We will devote two of our basebands to wideband continuum observations, so we use a bandwidth of 3.75 GHz when calculating the exposure time required to achieve the requested sensitivity.
We will devote our remaining two basebands to spectral line observations. In order to spectrally resolve emission from a Keplerian disk, a spectral resolution of <0.5 km/s is needed. The linewidths of our targets are also not expected to be greater than ~10 km/s so we do not need an overly wide spectral window. We therefore request a spectral resolution of ~0.1 km/s to well resolve the Keplerian rotation in the disk. For our source estimates we list the line width as 5 km/s and the peak line flux density as 1 Jy, comparable to previous observations of similar spectral lines of Class I protostars (e.g. Jorgensen et al. 2009).
A few of our targets (IRAS 04166 and IRAS 04365) have been previously observed with ALMA, however they have not been observed in Band 7. Furthermore, previous observations achieved a spatial resolution no better than 0.54", insufficient to well resolve the planet forming regions in the disks around Class I protostars. We therefore do not consider our requested observations to be a duplication of previous observations.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 680 GHz Continuum Observations
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: High spatial resolution observations of dust continuum emission from our sample of 11 Class I protostars.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We request 680 GHz continuum observations to complement our 345 GHz continuum observations. We request Band 9 because we can match the high spatial resolution of our 345 GHz continuum observations and because it provides a significantly longer wavelength baseline than Band 8 at 450 GHz does for constraining the spectral index of dust opacity (beta) in the disks around our targets.
We request high spatial resolution so that we can well resolve the compact disks, and more importantly the planet forming regions in those disks, around Class I protostars. Planets are expected to form within a radius of ~50 AU, or a 0.6" diameter at 140 pc, so the requested resolution, of ~0.1" is essential for resolving these regions. We also request observations with a more compact 12M configuration because the most extended 12M configuration will resolve out structures larger than ~1.3", or ~180 AU at 140 pc. As such we may resolve out part of our disks. The most compact configuration of the 12M array has a maximum recoverable scale of 3.8", or 530 AU at 140 pc. This is more than sufficient to resolve the compact disks around Class I protostars. We wish to constrain beta in the disk so we do not need the ACA to resolve larger scales.
Many of our targets have been previously observed at 1mm with a 1" beam (Eisner 2012) or with an 11" beam (Motte & Andre 2001). To estimate the flux per resolution element, of ~0.1" for the proposed extended configuration observations, we assume that previously measured millimeter fluxes for our targets trace an optically thin, face-on disk with a surface density profile Sigma ~ r^-1 and a temperature profile T ~ r^-0.5. We use that F_nu ~ nu^(2+beta) at millimeter wavelengths, with a reasonable assumption of beta=1 (e.g. Rodmann et al. 2006, Ricci et al. 2010a,b), to estimate the 450 micron fluxes. We find that our targets will have peak brightnesses of 100-1100 mJy/beam in a 0.09" beam. We list an expected peak flux density of 100 mJy for targets whose fluxes are unknown. We will devote all four of our basebands to continuum observations, so we use 7.5 GHz of bandwidth to calculate sensitivity. We request a sensitivity of 3.3 mJy so that we will be able to resolve extended structures with brightnesses 10 times fainter than peak brightness with a signal-to-noise of 3.
A few of our targets (IRAS 04166 and IRAS 04365) have previously been observed with ALMA, however those observations did not achieve a spatial resolution better than 0.54", which is insufficient to resolve the regions around Class I protostars where planets are formed. We do not consider our proposed observations to be duplicates.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Recent studies suggest that protoplanetary disks around 1-5 Myr old pre-main sequence stars contain insufficient mass to form giant planets. This may be because by this stage much of the material in the disk has already grown into larger bodies, hiding the material from sight. To test this hypothesis, we propose to observe a sample of 11 protostars in Taurus younger than 1 Myr, whose disks are more likely to represent the initial mass budget of protoplanetary disks for forming planets. We will measure the mass of the disks around these protostars, constrain the maximum dust grain sizes in the disks, constrain the geometry of the circumstellar material of these systems, and trace Keplerian rotation in the disks to measure the masses of the central protostars. By comparing the disk mass distribution and maximum dust grain sizes we derive for our sample with the existing 1-5 Myr old disk sample we will constrain the initial mass budget for forming planets in protoplanetary disks. We submitted a complementary proposal to repeat the experiment in Ophiuchus but kept the proposals separate as they explore different star forming regions and are each self contained.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: Disk Masses and Dust Grain Growth in Class I Protostars in Ophiuchus, Resolving Structure in the Planet Forming Regions of the Compact Binary Protostar GV Tau
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: Measuring the Masses of Disks Around Class I Protostars
